worklogs.comment:
bkietz commented on pull request #4782: ARROW-517: [C++] array comparison, uses D**2 space Myers
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4782
 
 
   Adds `arrow::Diff`, which compares two arrays returning an edit script which expresses the difference between them.
   
   The edit script is represented as an array of `struct<insert: bool, run_length: uint64_t>`.
   Each element of the "insert" column determines whether an element was inserted into (true) or deleted from (false) base. Each insertion or deletion is followed by a run of elements which are unchanged from base to target; the length of this run is stored in the "run_length" column. (The first element of the "insert" column is always false; the first element of the "run_length" column is the number of leading elements unchanged from base to target.)
   
   For example for base "hlloo" and target "hello", the edit script would be
   
   ```json
   [
     {"insert": true, "run_length": 1}, // leading run of length 1 ("h")
     {"insert": true, "run_length": 3}, // insert("e") then a run of length 3 ("llo")
     {"insert": false, "run_length": 0} // delete("o") then an empty run
   ]
   ```
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on to GitHub and use the

bkietz commented on issue #4782: ARROW-517: [C++] array comparison, uses D**2 space Myers
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4782#issuecomment-509278871
 
 
   An example of the output from the unified diff formatter:
   given base = `[0, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 11, 13, 17]`
   and target = `[2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13, 17, 19]`
   the diff will be rendered as:
   ```
   @@ -0, +0 @@
   -0
   -1
   @@ -5, +3 @@
   -8
   +7
   @@ -9, +7 @@
   +19
   ```
   
   Read: base begins with two elements not shared by target. The two arrays agree until element 5 of base (=8) and element 3 of target (=7). Finally, target ends with an element not shared by base (19)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

bkietz commented on issue #4782: ARROW-517: [C++] array comparison, uses D**2 space Myers
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/4782#issuecomment-510559367
 
 
   @xhochy I was thinking one the separated diff would be pretty useless when both dictionary and indices differ but `Take(dictionary, indices)` was close to invariant.
   
   For example, given dictionary encodings of `"abccab"` against differing dictionaries:
   
   given base dictionary `"abc"` it encodes to `[0, 1, 2, 2, 0, 1]` 
   but with target dictionary `"bca"` it encodes to `[1, 2, 0, 0, 1, 2]`
   
   A separated diff of the dictionaries is easy to understand but the diff of the indices is massive and definitely doesn't immediately tell you that the encoded sequence is identical. With a little legwork (unifying the dictionaries, for example) you can recover something useful but it won't work well out of the box.
   
   It's certainly not difficult to present the two diffs separately but its helpfulness seems more fragile than I'd like
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

   Interesting. I would expect an edit script to read more like this (for "hlloo" -> "hello"):
   ```
   {kind: unchanged, length: 1}
   {kind: deleted, length: 1}
   {kind: unchanged, length: 3}
   {kind: inserted, length: 1}
   ```
   
   Will take a look at the code at some point.

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

fields.description: In failing unit tests I often wished {{Array::Equals}} would tell me where they aren't equal. This would save a lot of time in debugging.

comments.body: As part of this, and also slightly related to ARROW-519, it would make sense to move the implementation details of {{Equals}} and {{ApproxEquals}} out of the {{arrow/array.h}} component. We can still have a base {{Array::Equals}} method that invokes the functions implemented in {{arrow/compare.h}} (or whatever we call it)
I'm refactoring the {{Array::Equals}} code path -- [~xhochy] if you were going to work on this could you hold off until I have a patch up? thanks

I don't think this is difficult to implement (probably want to add a {{verbose}} flag to {{RangeEqualsVisitor}} in {{compare.cc}}), but the one tedious item is that we need to implement string formatting functions for scalar values (i.e. something that knows how to write a human-readable value into an {{std::ostream}})
